text: Why HubSpot add a Canonical tag with the page URL by default in the <head/> ?
I just noticed it when trying to add a canonical tag to another page on one of my page. So in the source i have 2 tags. HubSpot’s default one first, then  mine.
Ok, i just saw the “Add self-referencing canonical URLs to all pages and blog posts (Recommended)” - but why it’s recommended to have a self referencing canonical tag?

Its because say you have a url like:
`<http://www.example.com/page>` and on that page you have parameters being passed over like `<http://www.example.com/page?id=123>` if people start linking over to your page with the parameters, this would cause search engines to not know which page is the proper one as all these URLS would be treated differently:
```
<http://www.example.com/page>
<http://www.example.com/page?id=213>
<http://www.example.com/page?param2=2345>
```
Having a self referencing canonical on the page will help to always tell the search engines which is the correct on to always use which would be the URL without the params
Yoast has a pretty good write up about canonicals and a section on this: <https://yoast.com/rel-canonical/#self-referencing>
